subclause.title: SubClause
subclause.p: The air-conditioning, must be modelled on the basis of—

ol.li: the daily occupancy and operation profiles in Tables S35C2a, S35C2b, S35C2c, S35C2d, S35C2e, S35C2f, S35C2g, S35C2h, S35C2i, S35C2j and S35C2k; and

the internal heat gains in a building—
from occupants and hot meals, in accordance with one of the options in Table S35C2n; and
from appliances and equipment, in accordance with Table S35C2l; and
from artificial lighting, determined in accordance with (2).

subclause.title: SubClause
subclause.p: The artificial lighting, must be modelled on the basis of the proposed level of artificial lighting in the building with the daily profile in Tables S35C2a, S35C2b, S35C2c, S35C2d, S35C2e, S35C2f, S35C2g, S35C2h, S35C2i, S35C2j and S35C2k.

subclause.title: SubClause
subclause.p: The heated water supply, must be modelled on the basis of the consumption rates of Table S35C2m.

table-reference.title: Occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 2 common area

desc-note.p: The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.

table-reference.title: Occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 3 hotel

ol.li: The occupancy profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum number of people that can be accommodated in the Class 3 building.
The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.
The air-conditioning profile is expressed as the plant status.

table-reference.title: Weekday occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 5 building, a Class 7 warehouse, a Class 8 Laboratory or a Class 9a clinic, day surgery or procedure unit

ol.li: The occupancy profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum number of people that can be accommodated in the building.
The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.
The appliances and equipment profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum internal heat gain in Table S35C2I.
The air-conditioning profile is expressed as the plant status.

table-reference.title: Weekend occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 5 building, a Class 7 warehouse, a Class 8 Laboratory or a Class 9a clinic, day surgery or procedure unit

row.entry: Appliances and equipment (Saturday, Sunday and holidays)

ol.li: The occupancy profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum number of people that can be accommodated in the building.
The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.
The appliances and equipment profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum internal heat gain in Table S35C2l.
The air-conditioning profile is expressed as the plant status.

table-reference.title: Occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 6 shop or shopping centre

ol.li: The occupancy profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum number of people that can be accommodated in the building.
The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.
The appliances and equipment profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum internal heat gain in S35C2l.
The air-conditioning profile is expressed as the plant status.

table-reference.title: Occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 6 restaurant or cafe

ol.li: The occupancy profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum number of people that can be accommodated in the building.
The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.
The appliances and equipment profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum internal heat gain in S35C2l.
The air-conditioning profile is expressed as the plant status.
Sunday profile is 5% continuous artificial lighting and 5% continuous appliances and equipment where there is no occupancy and the air-conditioning is “off”.

table-reference.title: Occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 9a ward area

ol.li: The occupancy profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum number of people that can be accommodated in the building.
The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.
The air-conditioning profile is expressed as the plant status.

table-reference.title: Occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 9b theatre or cinema

ol.li: The occupancy profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum number of people that can be accommodated in the building.
The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.
The air-conditioning profile is expressed as the plant status.

table-reference.title: Occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 9b conference facility

ol.li: The occupancy profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum number of people that can be accommodated in the building.
The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.
The appliances and equipment profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum internal heat gain in S35C2l.
The air-conditioning profile is expressed as the plant status.

table-reference.title: Occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 9b school

ol.li: The occupancy profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum number of people that can be accommodated in the building.
The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.
The appliances and equipment profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum internal heat gain in S35C2l.
The air-conditioning profile is expressed as the plant status.
Saturday and Sunday profiles are 5% continuous artificial lighting and 5% continuous appliances and equipment, where there is no occupancy and the air-conditioning is “off”.

table-reference.title: Occupancy and operation profiles of a Class 9c aged care facility

ol.li: The occupancy profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum number of people that can be accommodated in the Class 9c building.
The artificial lighting profile is expressed as a percentage of the maximum illumination power density permitted under Part J7.
The air-conditioning profile is expressed as the plant status.

table-reference.title: Internal heat gains for appliances and equipment

row.entry: 5 W/m2 averaged for 24 hours per day, 7 days per week, continuous operation
Class 8 laboratory and a Class 9a clinic, day surgery and a procedure unit
Class 6 shop and shopping centre, Class 6 cafe and restaurant and Class 9b school
150 W per room plus 10 W per person
Residential part of a hotel or motel
Dormitory, boarding house, guest house, hostel, lodging house and backpackers accommodation
Residential part of a school, accommodation for the aged, children or people with a disability and a detention centre or a health-care building which accommodates members of staff
Office, laboratory, shop and assembly building

table-reference.title: Internal heat gains for occupants and hot meals

row.entry: 80 W sensible heat gain and 80 W latent heat gain
The average adjusted metabolic rate for sedentary work from Table 45 of AIRAH-DA09
The heat emission rate for sedentary work from Table 6.3 of CIBSE Guide A
75 W sensible heat gain and 55 W latent heat gain
An average adjusted metabolic rate from Table 45 of AIRAH-DA09
A heat emission rate from Table 6.3 of CIBSE Guide A

ol.li: The number of people must be calculated in accordance with D2D18.
For a dining room, restaurant or cafe, the internal heat gains per person account for heat gains from both occupants and hot meals.
For other applications, the internal heat gains per person only account for heat gains from occupants.
